Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji, a Japanese poet and writer who was active in the early 20th century. Centered on Miyazawa’s own life, the film depicts his adolescence in the country, the ideals he pursued, and the ideological struggle between those ideals and his family’s declining fortunes.
The silent film depicts the war efforts in China during WWII through a series of photographs and stills with music playing in the background.

Well I don't know much about anything, but I sure liked this film. In short, it was creative, humorous, simple, and heartwarming. Okay, since you want to know, I'll explain.

I'd even say some shades of Hitchcock...this is clearly better than MMM, which is seen as a guilty pleasure by some if not most Woody fans.
Hate is too strong a word...but I don't regret hating the film in those days

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. "Les Valseuses" was remade as "Honeygivers" by Zhang Miaoyan and as "The Great Happiness Space", directed by Jake Moe, but I have never seen either of them. If you are a fan of Zorro, Indiana Jones, or action in general this is a must-see. A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The film, based on a short story by Raymond Carver, was directed by John Erick Dowdle (Quarantine, Breach and The Last House on the Left).
A story of a man who is living his life but also a story of a boy and his quest to love his father.
